Quantum Game Theory in Finance   This is a short review of the background and recent development in quantum
game theory and its possible application in economics and finance. The
intersection of science and society is also discussed. The review is addressed
to non--specialists.
 Quantum Physics, Physics (Other), Physics (Physics and Society)

Using pseudo-parabolic and fractional equations for option pricing in
  jump diffusion models   In mathematical finance a popular approach for pricing options under some
Levy model is to consider underlying that follows a Poisson jump diffusion
process. As it is well known this results in a partial integro-differential
equation (PIDE) that usually does not allow an analytical solution while
numerical solution brings some problems. In this paper we elaborate a new
approach on how to transform the PIDE to some class of so-called
pseudo-parabolic equations which are known in mathematics but are relatively
new for mathematical finance. As an example we discuss several jump-diffusion
models which Levy measure allows such a transformation.
 , 

Illustrating a problem in the self-financing condition in two 2010-2011
  papers on funding, collateral and discounting   We illustrate a problem in the self-financing condition used in the papers
"Funding beyond discounting: collateral agreements and derivatives pricing"
(Risk Magazine, February 2010) and "Partial Differential Equation
Representations of Derivatives with Counterparty Risk and Funding Costs" (The
Journal of Credit Risk, 2011). These papers state an erroneous self-financing
condition. In the first paper, this is equivalent to assuming that the equity
position is self-financing on its own and without including the cash position.
In the second paper, this is equivalent to assuming that a subportfolio is
self-financing on its own, rather than the whole portfolio. The error in the
first paper is avoided when clearly distinguishing between price processes,
dividend processes and gain processes. We present an outline of the derivation
that yields the correct statement of the self-financing condition, clarifying
the structure of the relevant funding accounts, and show that the final result
in "Funding beyond discounting" is correct, even if the self-financing
condition stated is not.
 , , 

ARCH and GARCH Models vs. Martingale Volatility of Finance Market
  Returns   ARCH and GARCH models assume either i.i.d. or (what economists lable as)
white noise as is usual in regression analysis while assuming memory in a
conditional mean square fluctuation with stationary increments. We will show
that ARCH/GARCH is inconsistent with uncorrelated increments, violating the
i.i.d. and white assumptions and finance data and the efficient market
hypothesis as well.
 , Physics (Data Analysis; Statistics and Probability), Physics (Physics and Society)

Pricing, liquidity and the control of dynamic systems in finance and
  economics   The paper discusses various practical consequences of treating economics and
finance as an inherently dynamic and chaotic system. On the theoretical side
this looks at the general applicability of the market-making pricing approach
to economics in general. The paper also discuses the consequences of the
endogenous creation of liquidity and the role of liquidity as a state variable.
On the practical side, proposals are made for reducing chaotic behaviour in
both housing markets and stock markets.


A New Kind of Finance   Finance has benefited from the Wolfram's NKS approach but it can and will
benefit even more in the future, and the gains from the influence may actually
be concentrated among practitioners who unintentionally employ those principles
as a group.


Hedging The Risk In The Continuous Time Option Pricing Model With
  Stochastic Stock Volatility   In this work, I address the issue of forming riskless hedge in the continuous
time option pricing model with stochastic stock volatility. I show that it is
essential to verify whether the replicating portfolio is self-financing, in
order for the theory to be self-consistent. The replicating methods in existing
finance literature are shown to violate the self-financing constraint when the
underlying asset has stochastic volatility. Correct self-financing hedge is
formed in this article.
 Physics (Statistical Mechanics), 

Fractional processes as models in stochastic finance   We survey some new progress on the pricing models driven by fractional
Brownian motion \cb{or} mixed fractional Brownian motion. In particular, we
give results on arbitrage opportunities, hedging, and option pricing in these
models. We summarize some recent results on fractional Black & Scholes pricing
model with transaction costs. We end the paper by giving some approximation
results and indicating some open problems related to the paper.
 , Mathematics (Probability), , 

Convex duality in stochastic programming and mathematical finance   This paper proposes a general duality framework for the problem of minimizing
a convex integral functional over a space of stochastic processes adapted to a
given filtration. The framework unifies many well-known duality frameworks from
operations research and mathematical finance. The unification allows the
extension of some useful techniques from these two fields to a much wider class
of problems. In particular, combining certain finite-dimensional techniques
from convex analysis with measure theoretic techniques from mathematical
finance, we are able to close the duality gap in some situations where
traditional topological arguments fail.
 , Mathematics (Optimization and Control), 

Volatility made observable at last   The Cartier-Perrin theorem, which was published in 1995 and is expressed in
the language of nonstandard analysis, permits, for the first time perhaps, a
clear-cut mathematical definition of the volatility of a financial asset. It
yields as a byproduct a new understanding of the means of returns, of the beta
coefficient, and of the Sharpe and Treynor ratios. New estimation techniques
from automatic control and signal processing, which were already successfully
applied in quantitative finance, lead to several computer experiments with some
quite convincing forecasts.
 , Computer Science (Computational Engineering; Finance; and Science),

    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0406129v1</id>
    <updated>2004-06-18T12:50:24Z</updated>
    <published>2004-06-18T12:50:24Z</published>
    <title>Quantum Game Theory in Finance</title>
    <summary>  This is a short review of the background and recent development in quantum
game theory and its possible application in economics and finance. The
intersection of science and society is also discussed. The review is addressed
to non--specialists.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Edward W. Piotrowski</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>J. Sladkowski</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">18 pages; a solicited paper for Quantitative Finance</arxiv:comment>
    <arxiv:journal_ref xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Abbreviated version was published in Quantitative Finance 4 (2004)
  1-7</arxiv:journal_ref>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0406129v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/quant-ph/0406129v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1002.1995v1</id>
    <updated>2010-02-09T22:43:36Z</updated>
    <published>2010-02-09T22:43:36Z</published>
    <title>Using pseudo-parabolic and fractional equations for option pricing in
  jump diffusion models</title>
    <summary>  In mathematical finance a popular approach for pricing options under some
Levy model is to consider underlying that follows a Poisson jump diffusion
process. As it is well known this results in a partial integro-differential
equation (PIDE) that usually does not allow an analytical solution while
numerical solution brings some problems. In this paper we elaborate a new
approach on how to transform the PIDE to some class of so-called
pseudo-parabolic equations which are known in mathematics but are relatively
new for mathematical finance. As an example we discuss several jump-diffusion
models which Levy measure allows such a transformation.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Andrey Itkin</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Peter Carr</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">37 pages, 16 figures. submitted to Applied Mathematical Finance.
  submitted to Applied Mathematical Finance</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1002.1995v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1002.1995v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="q-fin.CP" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.CP" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.PR" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1207.2316v2</id>
    <updated>2012-07-16T19:40:25Z</updated>
    <published>2012-07-10T11:49:03Z</published>
    <title>Illustrating a problem in the self-financing condition in two 2010-2011
  papers on funding, collateral and discounting</title>
    <summary>  We illustrate a problem in the self-financing condition used in the papers
"Funding beyond discounting: collateral agreements and derivatives pricing"
(Risk Magazine, February 2010) and "Partial Differential Equation
Representations of Derivatives with Counterparty Risk and Funding Costs" (The
Journal of Credit Risk, 2011). These papers state an erroneous self-financing
condition. In the first paper, this is equivalent to assuming that the equity
position is self-financing on its own and without including the cash position.
In the second paper, this is equivalent to assuming that a subportfolio is
self-financing on its own, rather than the whole portfolio. The error in the
first paper is avoided when clearly distinguishing between price processes,
dividend processes and gain processes. We present an outline of the derivation
that yields the correct statement of the self-financing condition, clarifying
the structure of the relevant funding accounts, and show that the final result
in "Funding beyond discounting" is correct, even if the self-financing
condition stated is not.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Damiano Brigo</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Cristin Buescu</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Andrea Pallavicini</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Qing Liu</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">added references, a footnote and updated abstract</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1207.2316v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1207.2316v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="q-fin.PR" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.PR" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.RM" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="91B70, 91G10, 91G20, 91G40" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/0803.4480v1</id>
    <updated>2008-03-31T15:36:42Z</updated>
    <published>2008-03-31T15:36:42Z</published>
    <title>ARCH and GARCH Models vs. Martingale Volatility of Finance Market
  Returns</title>
    <summary>  ARCH and GARCH models assume either i.i.d. or (what economists lable as)
white noise as is usual in regression analysis while assuming memory in a
conditional mean square fluctuation with stationary increments. We will show
that ARCH/GARCH is inconsistent with uncorrelated increments, violating the
i.i.d. and white assumptions and finance data and the efficient market
hypothesis as well.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Joseph L. McCauley</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/0803.4480v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/0803.4480v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="q-fin.ST" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.ST" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="physics.data-an" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="physics.soc-ph" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1105.5503v1</id>
    <updated>2011-05-27T09:26:08Z</updated>
    <published>2011-05-27T09:26:08Z</published>
    <title>Pricing, liquidity and the control of dynamic systems in finance and
  economics</title>
    <summary>  The paper discusses various practical consequences of treating economics and
finance as an inherently dynamic and chaotic system. On the theoretical side
this looks at the general applicability of the market-making pricing approach
to economics in general. The paper also discuses the consequences of the
endogenous creation of liquidity and the role of liquidity as a state variable.
On the practical side, proposals are made for reducing chaotic behaviour in
both housing markets and stock markets.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Geoff Willis</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1105.5503v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1105.5503v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="q-fin.GN" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.GN" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1210.1588v1</id>
    <updated>2012-10-04T20:28:37Z</updated>
    <published>2012-10-04T20:28:37Z</published>
    <title>A New Kind of Finance</title>
    <summary>  Finance has benefited from the Wolfram's NKS approach but it can and will
benefit even more in the future, and the gains from the influence may actually
be concentrated among practitioners who unintentionally employ those principles
as a group.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Philip Z. Maymin</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">13 pages; Forthcoming in "Irreducibility and Computational
  Equivalence: 10 Years After Wolfram's A New Kind of Science," Hector Zenil,
  ed., Springer Verlag, 2013</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1210.1588v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1210.1588v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="q-fin.CP" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.CP" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/cond-mat/9807066v1</id>
    <updated>1998-07-04T19:47:35Z</updated>
    <published>1998-07-04T19:47:35Z</published>
    <title>Hedging The Risk In The Continuous Time Option Pricing Model With
  Stochastic Stock Volatility</title>
    <summary>  In this work, I address the issue of forming riskless hedge in the continuous
time option pricing model with stochastic stock volatility. I show that it is
essential to verify whether the replicating portfolio is self-financing, in
order for the theory to be self-consistent. The replicating methods in existing
finance literature are shown to violate the self-financing constraint when the
underlying asset has stochastic volatility. Correct self-financing hedge is
formed in this article.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>D. F. Wang</name>
      <arxiv:affiliation xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">TD Bank and Univ. of Waterloo</arxiv:affiliation>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">8 pages, Revtex style</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/cond-mat/9807066v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/cond-mat/9807066v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="cond-mat.stat-mech" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="cond-mat.stat-mech" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.PR" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1004.3106v1</id>
    <updated>2010-04-19T06:46:59Z</updated>
    <published>2010-04-19T06:46:59Z</published>
    <title>Fractional processes as models in stochastic finance</title>
    <summary>  We survey some new progress on the pricing models driven by fractional
Brownian motion \cb{or} mixed fractional Brownian motion. In particular, we
give results on arbitrage opportunities, hedging, and option pricing in these
models. We summarize some recent results on fractional Black &amp; Scholes pricing
model with transaction costs. We end the paper by giving some approximation
results and indicating some open problems related to the paper.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Christian Bender</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Tommi Sottinen</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Esko Valkeila</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">To appear in Advanced Mathematical Methods for Finance (Eds. G. Di
  Nunno and B. {\O}ksendal Series in Mathematical Finance, Springer)</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1004.3106v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1004.3106v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="q-fin.PR" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.PR" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.PR" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.CP" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="91B28, 91B70, 60G15, 60H05" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1006.4083v1</id>
    <updated>2010-06-21T14:39:50Z</updated>
    <published>2010-06-21T14:39:50Z</published>
    <title>Convex duality in stochastic programming and mathematical finance</title>
    <summary>  This paper proposes a general duality framework for the problem of minimizing
a convex integral functional over a space of stochastic processes adapted to a
given filtration. The framework unifies many well-known duality frameworks from
operations research and mathematical finance. The unification allows the
extension of some useful techniques from these two fields to a much wider class
of problems. In particular, combining certain finite-dimensional techniques
from convex analysis with measure theoretic techniques from mathematical
finance, we are able to close the duality gap in some situations where
traditional topological arguments fail.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Teemu Pennanen</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1006.4083v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1006.4083v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="q-fin.CP" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.CP" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.OC" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="52A41, 46A20, 91B25, 90C15, 52A07" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.0683v1</id>
    <updated>2011-02-03T13:46:49Z</updated>
    <published>2011-02-03T13:46:49Z</published>
    <title>Volatility made observable at last</title>
    <summary>  The Cartier-Perrin theorem, which was published in 1995 and is expressed in
the language of nonstandard analysis, permits, for the first time perhaps, a
clear-cut mathematical definition of the volatility of a financial asset. It
yields as a byproduct a new understanding of the means of returns, of the beta
coefficient, and of the Sharpe and Treynor ratios. New estimation techniques
from automatic control and signal processing, which were already successfully
applied in quantitative finance, lead to several computer experiments with some
quite convincing forecasts.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Michel Fliess</name>
      <arxiv:affiliation xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">LIX</arxiv:affiliation>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Cédric Join</name>
      <arxiv:affiliation xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">INRIA Saclay - Ile de France, CRAN</arxiv:affiliation>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Frédéric Hatt</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:journal_ref xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">3\`emes Journ\'ees Identification et Mod\'elisation
  Exp\'erimentale, Douai : France (2011)</arxiv:journal_ref>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.0683v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1102.0683v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="q-fin.CP" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.CP" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="cs.CE" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="q-fin.ST" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>

Quantum Game Theory in Finance   This is a short review of the background and recent development in quantum
game theory and its possible application in economics and finance. The
intersection of science and society is also discussed. The review is addressed
to non--specialists.
 Quantum Physics, Physics (Other), Physics (Physics and Society)

Using pseudo-parabolic and fractional equations for option pricing in
  jump diffusion models   In mathematical finance a popular approach for pricing options under some
Levy model is to consider underlying that follows a Poisson jump diffusion

models which Levy measure allows such a transformation.

Sid: 20121203.001026.674.2

02.12.2012 23:10:26.780642 SYNCHED (20121203.001026.674.2,search)
02.12.2012 23:10:26.808271 UPDATED (20121203.001026.674.2,search)
02.12.2012 23:10:26.808470 EXIT SYNCH (20121203.001026.674.2,search)

02.12.2012 23:10:26.810326 ENTER SYNCH (20121203.001026.674.2,/rodin/eng/app/w/RDW_Arxiv.rodin)

DOCUMENTS (sid,body or cached info):
--------------

Sid: 20121203.001026.674.2
Body:
Quantum Game Theory in Finance   This is a short review of the background and recent development in quantum
game theory and its possible application in economics and finance. The
intersection of science and society is also discussed. The review is addressed
to non--specialists.
 Quantum Physics, Physics (Other), Physics (Physics and Society)

Sid: 20121203.001026.674.2
Body:
Using pseudo-parabolic and fractional equations for option pricing in
  jump diffusion models   In mathematical finance a popular approach for pricing options under some
Levy model is to consider underlying that follows a Poisson jump diffusion
process. As it is well known this results in a partial integro-differential
equation (PIDE) that usually does not allow an analytical solution while
numerical solution brings some problems. In this paper we elaborate a new
approach on how to transform the PIDE to some class of so-called
pseudo-parabolic equations which are known in mathematics but are relatively
new for mathematical finance. As an example we discuss several jump-diffusion
models which Levy measure allows such a transformation.
 , 

Sid: 20121203.001026.674.2
Body:
Illustrating a problem in the self-financing condition in two 2010-2011
  papers on funding, collateral and discounting   We illustrate a problem in the self-financing condition used in the papers
"Funding beyond discounting: collateral agreements and derivatives pricing"
(Risk Magazine, February 2010) and "Partial Differential Equation
Representations of Derivatives with Counterparty Risk and Funding Costs" (The
Journal of Credit Risk, 2011). These papers state an erroneous self-financing
condition. In the first paper, this is equivalent to assuming that the equity
position is self-financing on its own and without including the cash position.
In the second paper, this is equivalent to assuming that a subportfolio is
self-financing on its own, rather than the whole portfolio. The error in the
first paper is avoided when clearly distinguishing between price processes,
dividend processes and gain processes. We present an outline of the derivation
that yields the correct statement of the self-financing condition, clarifying
the structure of the relevant funding accounts, and show that the final result
in "Funding beyond discounting" is correct, even if the self-financing
condition stated is not.
 , , 

Sid: 20121203.001026.674.2
Body:
ARCH and GARCH Models vs. Martingale Volatility of Finance Market
  Returns   ARCH and GARCH models assume either i.i.d. or (what economists lable as)
white noise as is usual in regression analysis while assuming memory in a
conditional mean square fluctuation with stationary increments. We will show
that ARCH/GARCH is inconsistent with uncorrelated increments, violating the
i.i.d. and white assumptions and finance data and the efficient market
hypothesis as well.
 , Physics (Data Analysis; Statistics and Probability), Physics (Physics and Society)

Sid: 20121203.001026.674.2
Body:
Pricing, liquidity and the control of dynamic systems in finance and
  economics   The paper discusses various practical consequences of treating economics and
finance as an inherently dynamic and chaotic system. On the theoretical side
this looks at the general applicability of the market-making pricing approach
to economics in general. The paper also discuses the consequences of the
endogenous creation of liquidity and the role of liquidity as a state variable.
On the practical side, proposals are made for reducing chaotic behaviour in
both housing markets and stock markets.


Sid: 20121203.001026.674.2
Body:
A New Kind of Finance   Finance has benefited from the Wolfram's NKS approach but it can and will
benefit even more in the future, and the gains from the influence may actually
be concentrated among practitioners who unintentionally employ those principles
as a group.


Sid: 20121203.001026.674.2
Body:
Hedging The Risk In The Continuous Time Option Pricing Model With
  Stochastic Stock Volatility   In this work, I address the issue of forming riskless hedge in the continuous
time option pricing model with stochastic stock volatility. I show that it is
essential to verify whether the replicating portfolio is self-financing, in
order for the theory to be self-consistent. The replicating methods in existing
finance literature are shown to violate the self-financing constraint when the
underlying asset has stochastic volatility. Correct self-financing hedge is
formed in this article.
 Physics (Statistical Mechanics), 

Sid: 20121203.001026.674.2
Body:
Fractional processes as models in stochastic finance   We survey some new progress on the pricing models driven by fractional
Brownian motion \cb{or} mixed fractional Brownian motion. In particular, we
give results on arbitrage opportunities, hedging, and option pricing in these
models. We summarize some recent results on fractional Black & Scholes pricing
model with transaction costs. We end the paper by giving some approximation
results and indicating some open problems related to the paper.
 , Mathematics (Probability), , 

Sid: 20121203.001026.674.2
Body:
Convex duality in stochastic programming and mathematical finance   This paper proposes a general duality framework for the problem of minimizing
a convex integral functional over a space of stochastic processes adapted to a
given filtration. The framework unifies many well-known duality frameworks from
operations research and mathematical finance. The unification allows the
extension of some useful techniques from these two fields to a much wider class
of problems. In particular, combining certain finite-dimensional techniques
from convex analysis with measure theoretic techniques from mathematical
finance, we are able to close the duality gap in some situations where
traditional topological arguments fail.
 , Mathematics (Optimization and Control), 

Sid: 20121203.001026.674.2
Body:
Volatility made observable at last   The Cartier-Perrin theorem, which was published in 1995 and is expressed in
the language of nonstandard analysis, permits, for the first time perhaps, a
clear-cut mathematical definition of the volatility of a financial asset. It
yields as a byproduct a new understanding of the means of returns, of the beta
coefficient, and of the Sharpe and Treynor ratios. New estimation techniques
from automatic control and signal processing, which were already successfully
applied in quantitative finance, lead to several computer experiments with some
quite convincing forecasts.
 , Computer Science (Computational Engineering; Finance; and Science),

Body:

a convex integral functional over a space of stochastic processes adapted to a

Sid: 20121203.003646.497.2
Body:
